evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the operation of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA event on 12-25, with no contradictory information undermining this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, including crew interaction and coordination failures.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the operation of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The lack of warnings or interventions implies communication breakdown
Crew roles and qualifications imply expected communication responsibilities
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If the crew had explicitly warned or corrected each other timely
If the incident was caused by external factors unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows multiple crew members failed to communicate or intervene as the aircraft passed the Tug Release Point, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown during the operation of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcript of all communications; some assumptions about intent and awareness

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, including crew interaction and coordination failures.

assumptions: The described crew roles and interactions correspond to the 'crew' in the claim
The incident described is representative of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If the crew had explicitly communicated and coordinated properly during the pushback

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows communication and coordination failures among the crew: the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not speak up when the instructor passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence about explicit communication exchanges and crew coordination protocols

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable on the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA as of 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as of 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency must align with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model as of 12-25.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable on the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA as of 12-25.

assumptions: Assuming that the TRP markings mentioned are the relevant environmental/marking features in question.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the Tug Release Point (TRP) markings were missing, unclear, or otherwise deficient on 12-25 for this aircraft, that would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as of 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction in the aircraft during the event were presented.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the incident; all evidence points to human factors and procedural issues during pushback.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is applicable and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA on the date 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is robust against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and operational characteristics of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as observed on 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is applicable and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA on the date 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback was executed strictly according to procedure without passing the TRP
If the aircraft or date were different
If the procedural deviation was not observable or applicable to this aircraft type or registration

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes a procedural deviation during pushback of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25, where the aircraft passed the Tug Release Point and collided with the blast barrier (H4, H6). The TRP location and clearance for this aircraft type are specified (H7). Multiple witnesses confirm the pushback continued beyond the TRP without stopping as expected (H8, H10, H12).

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA event on 12-25, with no contradictory information undermining this root cause.

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members effectively communicated warnings or corrected the instructor, or if alternative causes were identified undermining communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) directly supports that communication and coordination breakdown occurred without contradictory information; crew members did not warn or question the instructor despite the pushback continuing past the TRP, indicating resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statements about other potential causes or contradicting communications; limited to crew statements and observations.
